data.title: completionItem snippets conflict with signatureHelp
data.body:
When implementing a [java language server](https://github.com/georgewfraser/vscode-javac), it would be nice to be able to activate signatureHelp immediately, without a trigger character. Suppose for example the user has typed:

    someValue.someMeth

We would like to autocomplete `someValue.someMethod()` and place the users cursor between parentheses. This is possible using snippets:

    CompletionItem { label: someMethod, insertText: someMethod($0), insertTextFormat: 2 }

The problem is that signatureHelp relies on the trigger character `(`, and it doesn't get activated when the `(` is inserted as part of the snippet.

This problem does not come up in languages like Typescript, because the expression `someValue.someMethod` is well-defined as a reference to `someMethod`. But in Java, method references have a different syntax `someValue::someMethod`. So we know the user will always type `(`, but we don't autocomplete it.

There are two possible solutions to this, one at the VSCode level and one at the language-server-protocol level:
1. VSCode solution: if the character before `$0` in a snippet is a signatureHelp trigger character, activate signatureHelp.
1. LSP solution: add a property `CompletionItem { ... activateSignatureHelp: boolean }` that activates signature-help immediately following completion.

I filed a corresponding issue in the language-server-protocol repo: https://github.com/Microsoft/language-server-protocol/issues/274

data.title: How much time Microsoft intends to employ on VSCode?
data.body:
It is very awesome the time employed by Microsoft workers/employers on developing VSCode, however how much time this dream is pretend to last?

As we may known every project has a determinate end, however the software life cycle never dies. There is always the maintenance process the project needs as minor changes and fixes from its dependencies updates, i.e., to be kept up to date with the state of the art.

Currently we may notice heavily contributions from the Microsoft team, but exactly how much time they are going to be present on the project? 

All of them are going to be committed for ever working with VSCode development? I can assume some of the, may be relocated to new projects. But this project is planed to be kept powered by Microsoft for how long and with how many man hours over the time period?

I can think that Microsoft has escalated, set goals of development to be achieved by this project, and after a certain time this project would end and a new project as a maintenance project would be place in action to provided maintenance for the project.

Who am I and why all those questions? I am just curious to see what is on the Microsoft's mind. Thought, I am coming from Sublime Text, a closed source project. I have been developing third part packages for it, but the Sublime Text development team does not bring much confidence on whether they can fix the core problems I have been experiencing. Therefore I am planing to move on to some new project which I can engage and not worry about unsolvable problems as low community support and segmentation faults on the software core.

On this context, or even today's context, the community support (a private team of workers also very welcome), is very important for the tool development not to stop and end up outdated. So here the point is, if I am going to be the only one working it, I am scrolled. Only by myself I cannot accomplish much in my whole life time. Hence where a great overall community support can help to solve the problem and keep the software in awesome shape.

data.title: Multi remote desktop session use of VS Code does not behave as expected

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

In [this video](https://thed3vine.net/files/QrzWV.mp4), you're looking at two Remote Desktop connections to the same machine. Notice how Code will only open in one session at a time. If a file is opened with Code and another session already has Code running, the file opens in that session instead of the intended one.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:1.14.2
- OS Version: Windows Server 2016 x64 1607 (14393.1480)

Steps to reproduce:
1. Have a machine with multiple active login sessions
2. Use Code on both sessions

What should have happened:
- Each session should have gotten its own copy of Code

What actually happened:
- Code only opened in one session at a time, and received open commands from other sessions

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Is there a way to force refresh of intellisense as a band-aid?

data.title: Feature request: Mac line ending selector
data.body:
Currently, the UI has two line ending settings:
- LF - Unix
- CR LF - Windows

However, there is a third type of line ending that crops up occasionally, sometimes called 'mac' line endings, it's just CR. Please consider adding it to the list for easy conversion.

data.title: Open With shows blank file in the place of the original file
data.body:
# Issue

The issue seems to be to do with the .desktop file distributed with 'code' requesting that 'code' be launched with file URIs which it can't handle. It should have an Exec argument of %F not %U

- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:26:08.116Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-83-generic
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
xml|Dot|1.9.2
python|don|0.6.9
cpptools|ms-|0.12.1

---

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Navigate to a folder on an LXDE Ubuntu Desktop
2. Use right-click menu to choose 'Open With' Visual Studio Code
3. Code editing window opens showing no code at all, even when file contains 1k of code
4. Turns out that it has opened a file called like /home/user/file:/home/user/folder/source.py since its .desktop file incorrectly requests a file:// URI which it can't handle

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->

I edited the /usr/share/applications/code.desktop to add the --disable-extensions flag, then shut down and relaunched from the finder. The same problem presents.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes 


# Workaround

I modified the /usr/share/applications/code.desktop file to fix the issue by changing the Exec line to read as follows...

```
Exec=/usr/share/code/code %F
``` 

...instead of the original which read...

```
Exec=/usr/share/code/code --unity-launch %U
```

After this, the issue went away.

data.title: Menu text is too small and barely readable
data.body:
Menu text is too small (2 times smaller than others), barely readable w/o any way to increase their size (`window.zoomLevel`, `editor.fontSize` doesn't affect them.):  
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1336703/28500454-55b2add4-6fd1-11e7-9863-14407641ef61.png))
Also it's hard to read light-grey text on dark grey background. Is there  any way it can be tuned?

My setup:
- VSCode Version: `1.14.2-1` from [aur](https://aur.archlinux.org/cgit/aur.git/tree/PKGBUILD?h=visual-studio-code)
- OS Version: ArchLinux + Kde (bleeding edge, latest)

data.title: Error code of zero in markers get removed
data.body: markerService.ts tries to [sanitize](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/caa0ef4e3a0128a73bfe51a32c1833dea4f63c35/src/vs/platform/markers/common/markerService.ts#L190) the marker data by checking the marker's `code` property. Unfortunately, if `code === 0` then it'll become `null`. This means that later attempts to access the created marker will not match "reality" because the `code` property is now `null`.

data.title: SavingProblem
data.body:
I saved some files, then the one I am looking at covered others. For example:
```
<!-- a.html -->
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>

<head>
    <title>Document</title>
</head>

<body>
</body>

</html>

/* b.css */
/* I'm looking at this file */
* {
    color: red;
}
```
When I leave the window, they save automatically, and *b.css* become:
```
<!DOCTYPE html><html><head><title>Document</title></head><body></body></html>
```

data.title: useNewEmmet doesn't evaluate an expression with a dash or double dash when TAB is pressed
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 and OS X Sierra

## Problem

While trying to expand an HTML emmet abbreviation, if the name of the CSS class contains one or two dashes (hyphens) then the expression doesn't expand and the TAB character is inserted instead,

This doesn't happen when `useNewEmmet` is set to `false`. It could be a very important bug because of the [BEM CSS Principles](http://getbem.com/introduction/) which advocate using classes with double hyphens and a lot of designers follow this pattern.

## Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write a CSS class with a hyphen in between or ending with a hyphen
2. Press the TAB key

Demo: http://i.imgur.com/Uo5FO9x.gif

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: useNewEmmet doesn't honor tab key in a specific usecase
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 and OS X Sierra

## Problem

when `useNewEmmet` is set to true, Emmet expressions are only evaluated if the tab key is pressed immediately after writing an expression and do not work for an existing string.

## Steps to Reproduce:

1. Type an emmet expression but don't press tab immediately
2. Move the cursor to different lines and go back to the emmet expression
3. Pressing TAB will insert a TAB stop instead of evaluating an emmet expression

Demo : http://i.imgur.com/b1rTXsz.gif
